questions.text: Identify the sign. (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Double ring sign

 

The image shows a radiograph with a distinct double ring appearance, which is characteristic of a button battery. A button battery has a three-dimensional structure with two concentric rings when viewed on X-ray, creating the "double ring sign." This appearance is diagnostic of a button battery, a common foreign object seen in pediatric radiographs.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. String sign: The string sign refers to a thin, string-like narrowing often associated with conditions like Crohn's disease or hypertrophic pyloric stenosis. It does not have the double ring appearance seen in this image.

 

Option C. Bird beak sign: The bird beak sign is associated with achalasia and appears as a tapering of the distal esophagus resembling a bird's beak. This sign does not resemble the double ring pattern shown in the image.

 

Option D. Double bubble sign: This sign is associated with duodenal atresia and appears as two bubbles (the stomach and the proximal duodenum) on an X-ray. It is distinct from the double ring pattern seen with a button battery.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The "double ring sign" on an X-ray is characteristic of a button battery, easily distinguishable by its unique appearance.

questions.text: Identify the marked structure:(INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Posterior rib

 

The marked structure in the provided chest X-ray image points to the horizontal part of the rib, which is indicative of the posterior rib. In radiographic anatomy, the posterior ribs are visualized as horizontal structures on a chest X-ray, whereas the anterior ribs appear more curved as they wrap around the thoracic cavity. This distinction is crucial for identifying the ribs accurately.

 

The posterior ribs are highlighted because they are flatter and more horizontal compared to the anterior ribs, which curve forward.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Anterior rib: The anterior ribs are more curved and not horizontal like the posterior ribs. The marked structure clearly shows a horizontal rib, which excludes the anterior rib as the correct answer.

 

Option C. Costal cartilage: Costal cartilage does not show up on standard X-rays because it is not as radiopaque as bone. Therefore, it cannot be the marked structure.

 

Option D. Pulmonary artery: The pulmonary artery would appear in the lung hilum and would not resemble the horizontal rib structure. Thus, it is not the correct answer.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The posterior rib appears as a horizontal structure on a chest X-ray, distinguishing it from the more curved anterior ribs and other thoracic structures.

questions.text: What is the diagnosis based on the CT image? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) PUJO (Pelviureteric Junction Obstruction)

 

The CT image shows a massively dilated renal pelvis with thinning of the renal parenchyma, which is characteristic of Pelviureteric Junction Obstruction (PUJO). In PUJO, the obstruction occurs at the junction between the renal pelvis and the ureter, causing the pelvis to become disproportionately dilated compared to the calyces. This results in significant thinning of the renal tissue, which is evident in the image. The appearance of a stretched and thin parenchyma alongside a dilated pelvis points towards PUJO.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A.  Renal cyst: A renal cyst typically appears as a single, fluid-filled, well-defined lesion within the kidney. The key feature is that it would appear as a solitary or few non-communicating cysts, unlike the diffuse dilation and thin parenchyma seen in PUJO.

 

Option C.  AD PCKD (Autosomal Dominant Polycystic Kidney Disease): AD PCKD is characterized by multiple cysts throughout the kidney, which are typically non-communicating and cause the kidneys to become enlarged and lobulated. In contrast, the CT here shows a single, large, dilated pelvis rather than multiple distinct cysts.

 

Option D.  Horseshoe kidney: A horseshoe kidney is a congenital condition where the kidneys are fused at the lower poles, forming a horseshoe shape. It does not present with significant pelvis dilation or obstructive features as seen in this CT image.

 

Educational Objective:

 

PUJO is characterized by massive dilation of the renal pelvis with thinning of the renal parenchyma due to obstruction at the pelviureteric junction. The pelvis is more dilated than the calyces, which is a hallmark finding on imaging.

questions.text: A 56-year-old female patient presented with a history of pathological fracture of the neck of femur. On lab investigations, ALP and N-telopeptide levels were raised. The DEXA scan confirmed the diagnosis as osteoporosis. Based on the lab values of osteoporosis, which other values will be raised in this patient? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Tartrate Resistant Acid Phosphatase

 

In osteoporosis, there is an imbalance between bone resorption (breakdown) and bone formation, with resorption exceeding formation. This leads to bone weakening, which is why the patient has a pathological fracture.

 

The key markers that are elevated in cases of osteoporosis include N & C terminal telopeptides and tartrate-resistant acid phosphatase (TRAP), which are markers of increased bone resorption. In osteoporosis, TRAP levels are elevated, indicating that bone destruction is occurring at a higher rate than formation.

 

Other markers like ALP (alkaline phosphatase) may also be raised, but the specific marker for bone resorption and the correct answer in this case is TRAP.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Alanine Transaminase: This is a liver enzyme commonly elevated in liver diseases, but it has no direct association with bone metabolism or osteoporosis.

 

Option B. Aspartate Aminotransferase: Like ALT, AST is another liver enzyme, primarily elevated in liver damage and certain heart conditions. It is unrelated to bone resorption or osteoporosis.

 

Option C. Lactate Dehydrogenase: LDH is an enzyme found in many tissues and may be elevated in conditions involving tissue breakdown, but it is not specific to bone resorption or osteoporosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tartrate-resistant acid phosphatase (TRAP) is elevated in osteoporosis due to increased bone resorption, making it a key marker for this condition.

questions.text: A child sustained a fracture after a fall. The post-op x-ray is shown below. The fracture will heal by which mechanism? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Primary healing

 

The x-ray shows a fracture that has been treated with plating. This suggests the fracture is undergoing primary healing, which occurs when there is rigid fixation (such as with plates). In primary healing, no callus formation is seen because the bone edges are closely approximated and there is minimal micromotion. Healing occurs through direct bone formation, and intramembranous ossification can be part of this process. However, the overall mechanism here is primary healing, which is specifically associated with rigid internal fixation like plating.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Creeping substitution: This refers to a bone graft healing mechanism where old bone is replaced by new bone. It does not apply to fracture healing in the context of this case.

 

Option B. Intramembranous ossification: While intramembranous ossification can be involved in primary bone healing, it is not the comprehensive mechanism. The broader term is primary healing, which includes processes like intramembranous ossification but is driven by rigid fixation.

 

Option D. Secondary healing: This involves callus formation and occurs when there is micromotion at the fracture site, as seen with casting or nailing. This is not applicable in this case, where rigid fixation (plating) is used, leading to primary healing.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Primary healing occurs with rigid fixation (such as plating) and involves direct bone formation without callus formation. Secondary healing involves callus formation and occurs when there is micromotion, typically seen with casts or nailing.

questions.text: A lady presented with a pelvic mass which was hyperintense on T1-weighted image, hyperintense on T1-fat saturated image, and hypointense on T2-weighted image with T2 shading. What is the likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Endometrioma

 

The imaging findings described are characteristic of an endometrioma. Endometriomas are cystic ovarian lesions filled with old blood, often referred to as "chocolate cysts." On MRI, these lesions typically appear hyperintense on T1-weighted images due to the presence of subacute or chronic blood products. On T1-fat saturated images, the mass remains hyperintense, confirming that the hyperintensity is due to blood rather than fat. The hallmark feature of an endometrioma is the T2 shading sign, which refers to the gradual decrease in signal intensity on T2-weighted images due to repeated hemorrhage and layering of blood products within the cyst.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Teratoma: Teratomas often contain fat, which would appear hyperintense on T1-weighted images but would become hypointense on T1-fat saturated sequences. The lack of T2 shading and persistence of T1 hyperintensity on fat saturation sequences make this diagnosis unlikely.

 

Option C. Carcinoma ovary: Carcinoma of the ovary usually appears as a solid or complex cystic mass with variable signal characteristics. It does not typically present with T1 hyperintensity due to fat or blood nor does it show T2 shading.

 

Option D. Dysgerminoma: Dysgerminomas are solid ovarian tumors that do not exhibit hyperintensity on T1-weighted images or T2 shading. They usually appear as large, solid masses with homogeneous or slightly heterogeneous signal intensities on MRI.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Endometriomas are characterized by T1 hyperintensity that persists on T1-fat saturated images and display the T2 shading sign, distinguishing them from other ovarian masses.

questions.text: A patient presenting with headaches, hypertension, and elevated metanephrines should undergo which diagnostic investigation? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) MIBG scan

 

  • Given the symptoms and the elevated metanephrines patient seems likely to have pheochromocytoma , and  an MIBG scan or a CT abdomen would be the most appropriate investigations to confirm the diagnosis of a pheochromocytoma. The MIBG scan offers more specific targeting of the type of tissue involved in pheochromocytoma, making it particularly useful if initial CT results are ambiguous or if surgical planning is necessary.
  • This is a specific type of scintigraphy used to locate neuroendocrine tumors, particularly pheochromocytomas. MIBG is structurally similar to norepinephrine and can be labeled with iodine-123 or iodine-131, allowing it to be visualized using a gamma camera.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Sestamibi Scan: This is primarily used for detecting parathyroid adenomas and is not suitable for diagnosing pheochromocytoma.

 

Option C. PET Scan (Positron Emission Tomography): While a PET scan is useful in oncologic imaging and can detect metabolically active tumors, it is not as specific as MIBG for pheochromocytoma but may be utilized depending on availability and specific circumstances.

 

Option D. CT Abdomen: This is an effective and rapid diagnostic tool to visualize the adrenal glands and assess for the presence of a tumor. A CT scan can provide detailed images that help in determining the size and location of adrenal masses.

 

Educational Objective :

 

  • Diagnostic investigation of choice for pheochromocytoma is MIBG scan.

questions.text: A young female patient complains of low back pain radiating to the right hip, back of the thigh, leg, and ankle after an intense workout of lifting some heavy weights. MRI shows the following finding. Which nerve root is most likely to be involved here? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) L5

 

The MRI provided shows a disc prolapse between the L4 and L5 vertebrae, which is a common site for disc herniation. In cases of disc herniation, the exiting nerve root is generally affected. The L5 nerve root is compressed in a typical L4-L5 disc prolapse, as the L5 nerve exits below the L5 vertebra. Disc herniations are usually postero-lateral, meaning the herniated material presses on the nerve root exiting the spinal cord below the level of the disc.

 

In this case, the symptoms described — radiating pain down the back of the thigh, leg, and ankle — are consistent with L5 nerve root involvement, as the L5 nerve innervates muscles in this area and also provides sensory innervation to the same region.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. S1: An S1 nerve root compression typically causes symptoms in the posterior leg and into the foot, especially affecting the lateral aspects of the foot and possibly the sole. This distribution is less aligned with the symptoms of the patient described, which are more characteristic of an L5 nerve root involvement.

 

Option B. L3: An L3 nerve root compression would cause pain in the front of the thigh, which is not the primary area of concern in this case. The patient’s symptoms include pain radiating to the posterior leg, more aligned with the L5 nerve.

 

Option C. L4: While an L4 nerve root can sometimes be compressed, this usually happens with a far-lateral disc herniation, which is less common than a postero-lateral disc herniation. The described pain in the back of the thigh, leg, and ankle is not typically associated with L4 nerve root compression.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In an L4-L5 disc prolapse, the L5 nerve root is most commonly compressed, causing pain radiating down the back of the thigh and into the leg and ankle.

questions.text: A patient underwent endoscopy, during the procedure perforation occurred at 25 cm from the incisors. Which structure is likely to be damaged? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Arch of aorta

 

During an endoscopy, if a perforation occurs at 25 cm from the incisors, the structure most likely to be damaged is the arch of the aorta. At this anatomical level, the esophagus is in close proximity to the arch of the aorta and the left bronchus. The esophagus traverses behind the arch of the aorta around this distance from the upper incisors, making it susceptible to injury in the event of a perforation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Diaphragm: The diaphragm is located approximately 40 cm from the incisors, much lower than the site of perforation.

 

Option C. Pharyngoesophageal junction: This junction is situated around 15 cm from the incisors, which is too high up the esophagus to be relevant to a perforation at 25 cm.

 

Option D. Right bronchus: The right bronchus is not in proximity to the esophagus at the 25 cm mark. It is the left bronchus that is close to the esophagus at this level, but it was not listed as an option.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Perforation at 25 cm from the incisors during endoscopy is most likely to involve the arch of the aorta due to its anatomical position relative to the esophagus.

questions.text: Match the following: (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) A-SVC, B-Aorta, C-Trachea, D-Esophagus

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. SVC - Superior Vena Cava: The structure marked as A is identified as the superior vena cava, which is located on the right side of the chest

 

Option B. Aorta: The structure labeled as B is the arch of the aorta, which appears as a large circular structure in the middle of the chest.

 

Option C. Trachea: The air-filled black structure identified as C is the trachea, which appears as a circular, air-filled structure in the middle of the chest on a CT scan.

 

Option D. Esophagus: The structure marked D is the esophagus, which lies posterior to the trachea and appears as a smaller circular structure on the scan.

 

The correct matching based on the image is option B: A-SVC, B-Aorta, C-Trachea, D-Esophagus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

When identifying structures on a chest CT, it's crucial to accurately recognize the anatomical positions of key structures like the superior vena cava, aorta, trachea, and esophagus based on their appearance and location in cross-sectional imaging.

questions.text: Intermittent dose of Parathyroid hormone causes risk of:  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Osteosarcoma

 

  • Intermittent doses of parathyroid hormone (PTH), specifically recombinant human PTH (teriparatide), are used in the treatment of osteoporosis and are associated with several risks and benefits.
  • Osteosarcoma is a type of bone cancer that has been associated with PTH therapy, but this risk is primarily a concern with long-term continuous exposure rather than intermittent dosing.
  • Mechanism: 
    • Long-term continuous PTH exposure has been shown to increase the risk of osteosarcoma in studies.
    • This is due to PTH's effects on bone remodeling and the potential stimulation of abnormal bone cell proliferation.
  • Teriparatide (intermittent PTH) is used for osteoporosis and involves daily injections of 20mcg for a limited period (usually up to 2 years).
  • Clinical trials and long-term studies have not shown a definitive increase in osteosarcoma risk with this intermittent therapy, but caution is advised as osteosarcoma is a rare complication of intermittent PTH.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Subtrochanteric Atypical Fracture: Subtrochanteric atypical fractures are a known risk associated with long-term bisphosphonate therapy, not intermittent PTH therapy. Bisphosphonates work by inhibiting bone resorption, which can lead to the accumulation of micro-damage in bones. Over time, this may result in atypical femoral fractures, including subtrochanteric fractures, often with minimal trauma.

 

Option C. Net Loss of Bone Mass: Net loss of bone mass is not a typical outcome of intermittent PTH therapy. Intermittent PTH therapy generally leads to an increase in bone mass and improves bone density, especially when used in conjunction with other osteoporosis treatments. PTH stimulates osteoblast activity, which increases bone formation.

 

Option D. Osteonecrosis of Jaw: Osteonecrosis of the jaw is a condition primarily associated with long-term use of bisphosphonates and other anti-resorptive therapies, not with intermittent PTH therapy. Osteonecrosis of the jaw is a severe condition where the jawbone becomes necrotic due to impaired blood supply, often linked to the suppression of bone resorption. This risk is notably higher with intravenous bisphosphonates and is associated with dental procedures or trauma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Osteosarcoma have indicated a potential risk with continuous and intermittent PTH administration, though it is rarely seen complication of intermittent PTH therapy.

questions.text: What is the likely diagnosis based on the given image? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Aberrant right subclavian artery

 

The CT scan image provided shows an anatomical variant where there is an extra vessel coursing behind the esophagus towards the right side. Normally, there are three major arch arteries visible at this level. However, in this image, an additional vessel is seen, which is characteristic of an aberrant right subclavian artery.

 

The aberrant right subclavian artery is an anatomical variation where the right subclavian artery arises as the fourth branch of the aortic arch and passes posterior to the esophagus. This can lead to a condition known as dysphagia lusoria, where the esophagus is compressed by the artery, causing difficulty in swallowing (dysphagia).

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Right sided aortic arch: This condition involves the aortic arch itself being positioned on the right side, which is not indicated by the presence of an extra vessel behind the esophagus in this image.

 

Option C. Tracheal diverticulum: A tracheal diverticulum would appear as an air-filled outpouching from the trachea. The image does not show any such outpouching or abnormality of the trachea.

 

Option D. Esophageal duplication: This is a rare congenital condition where a duplicated segment of the esophagus is present. The image does not show an additional lumen or any signs indicative of esophageal duplication.

 

Educational Objective:

 

An aberrant right subclavian artery is an anatomical variant where the artery arises as the fourth branch of the aortic arch and courses posterior to the esophagus, often leading to dysphagia lusoria due to esophageal compression.

questions.text: While examining a patient in supine position, the examiner keeps his hand below the heel of one foot and asks the patient to flex the other hip against resistance, while keeping the week leg straight. This is known as:(AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Hoover’s sign

 

HOOVER TEST:

 

  • Hoover’s sign is a maneuver to separate organic from non-organic paresis of Leg.
  • Principle: Synergistic Contraction.
  • Involuntary extension of normal leg occurs with flexion of contralateral limb against resistance.
  • Test Positioning:
    • The subject relaxes in a supine position on the table while the examiner places both of the subject’s heels into their palm.
  • Action:
    • The subject is asked to perform a unilateral straight leg raise.
  • Positive Finding:
    • The inability to lift the leg may reflect a neuromuscular weakness.
    • A positive finding is also noted when the examiner does not feel increased pressure in the palm that underlies the resting leg.
    • Organic Cause: Flexion of paralyzed limb → heel of normal limb pushes the examiner’s hand.
    • Functional Weakness: Heel does not pushdown, i.e. the effort is not being transmitted.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Waddell’s test. Tests of malingering. Each test counts as +1 if +ve, 0 if –ve. This includes Superficial skin tenderness to light pinch over wide area of lumbar spine; Deep tenderness over wide area, often extending to thoracic spine, sacrum, and/or pelvis; Low back pain on axial loading of spine in standing; SLR test positive in supine, but not when seated with knee extended to test Babinski reflex; Abnormal or inconsistent neurological (motor and/or sensory) patterns; Overreaction. If 3+ points or more are there, investigate for non-organic cause.

 

Option B. O’ Donoghue’s test. Structures affected: Cervical spinal muscles and/or cervical spinal ligaments. The cervical spine of a seated patient is passively flexed, extended, laterally flexed to both sides, and rotated in both directions against patient resistance. Pain precipitated by such isometric contraction indicates cervical strain. The test is then repeated without patient resistance. Pain precipitated by passive unrestricted motion signifies cervical sprain.

 

 

O’Donoghue’s Maneuver for Knee Joint: This maneuver can be used to diagnose meniscal pathologies in the knee. With the patient in prone, the examiner flexes the knee to 90° and then rotates the tibia internally and externally twice, then fully extends the knee and repeat the rotations. Increased pain during rotation in either or both knee positions indicates a meniscal tear or joint capsule irritation. With a valgus force to a flexed and laterally rotated knee, the medial meniscus, medial collateral ligament (MCL), and ACL all may be injured, representing the O'Donoghue triad.

 

Option D. McMurray test. This test indicates tears of the middle or posterior horn of the meniscus. With the patient supine and the hip and knee fully flexed, apply a valgus force and externally rotate the tibia while extending the knee. An audible or palpable pop or snap indicates a medial meniscal tear. Lesions of the lateral meniscus are tested by applying a varus force and internally rotating the tibia during knee extension. The snap is produced as the torn fragment rides over the femoral condyle during extension. A snap in extreme flexion is indicative of a posterior horn tear; a click at 90° of flexion indicates a lesion in the middle section of the meniscus. Only 57% of meniscal root tears result in a positive McMurray test. 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

While examining a patient in supine position, the examiner keeps his hand below the heel of one foot and asks the patient to flex the other hip against resistance, while keeping the week leg straight. This is known as Hoover’s sign.

questions.text: Which tendon is palpable behind the medial malleolus on inversion of the foot? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Posterior tibialis

 

The posterior tibialis tendon is located behind the medial malleolus, and it is palpable when the foot is inverted. This tendon is essential for supporting the arch of the foot and plays a significant role in foot inversion. During the movement of foot inversion, the posterior tibialis tendon becomes more prominent and easier to palpate behind the medial malleolus, which is the bony prominence on the inner side of the ankle.

 

The posterior tibialis tendon inserts on the navicular bone (sometimes referred to as the scaphoid of the foot). This tendon’s attachment helps maintain the foot's arch and aids in foot inversion.

 

Note - Kohler disease is a rare bone disorder that causes osteochondritis of the navicular bone in children.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Anterior tibialis: The anterior tibialis tendon is located on the anterior side of the ankle and foot. It is responsible for dorsiflexion (lifting the foot upward) and does not pass behind the medial malleolus, making it unpalpable in this area during inversion.

 

Option B. Extensor hallucis brevis: The extensor hallucis brevis is involved in extending the big toe. It does not run behind the medial malleolus and is located on the dorsum of the foot, so it is unrelated to the action of inversion or palpation behind the medial malleolus.

 

Option C. Extensor hallucis longus: This tendon extends the big toe and assists in dorsiflexion of the foot. It is found on the anterior aspect of the foot, not behind the medial malleolus, and is not palpable during inversion.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The posterior tibialis tendon is palpable behind the medial malleolus during inversion of the foot and inserts on the navicular bone.

questions.text:
Steps of surgery of DDH in a child < 2 years:(AIIMS NOV 2019)

 

  1. Capsulotomy
  2. Femoral osteotomy
  3. Identification of true acetabulum using round ligament
  4. Placing the head back into acetabulum
questions.solution:
Ans. C) a → c → b → d

 

DEVELOPMENTAL DYSPLASIA OF HIP (DDH)

 

  • This is a spontaneous dislocation of the hip occurring before, during or shortly after birth.
  • DDH is failure of maintenance of femoral head due to malformations of acetabulum or femur.
  • More common in girls usually seen on left side.

 

 

 

 

  • Treatment:

    • Surgical approach: 
      • The aim in DDH is to place the head of femur in acetabulum. 
      • Open the joint, identify the acetabulum, cut and rotate the femur and place the head in acetabulum.
    • Surgical procedure:
      • Percutaneous adductor tenotomy is performed in all patients prior to open reduction. 
      • The hip joint is approached superficially between sartorius and tensor fascia lata. 
      • The sartorius is detached from anterior superior iliac spine to improve exposure. 
      • The anteromedial capsule is incised to remove the obstacle to reduction. 
      • The femoral head is identified and ligamentum teres is cut and traced to the acetabulum. 
      • The psoas tendon is identified and tenotomy is done to improve access to the acetabulum. 
      • The acetabular labrum is identified and care is taken to keep it intact and undamaged. 
      • The transverse acetabular ligament is identified and incised to remove the inferior obstacle to reduction. 
      • The acetabulum is cleared of fibrocartilaginous tissue and femoral head is reduced into the acetabulum. 

     

Educational Objective:

 

The correct order of surgical procedure for DDH in a child < 2 years of age is: 

Capsulotomy

↓

Identification of true acetabulum using round ligament

↓

Femoral osteotomy

↓

Placing the head back into acetabulum

questions.text: A child had a fall at home and was treated with an elbow cast. After the removal of the cast, the child developed the deformity as shown. Which fracture most likely caused this deformity? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Supracondylar humerus fracture

 

The image shows a child with a deformity known as cubitus varus, which is a complication of supracondylar humerus fractures. This deformity occurs when the distal part of the arm deviates medially, leading to a "gunstock" appearance of the arm. Cubitus varus is a known consequence of a malunited supracondylar humerus fracture, where the carrying angle of the elbow is reduced.

 

Supracondylar fractures are common in children, especially after a fall on an outstretched hand, and improper alignment during healing can lead to this deformity. The deformity is mostly a cosmetic issue but is directly associated with this type of fracture.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Radial head fracture: Radial head fractures typically present with pain during rotation of the forearm and do not commonly cause cubitus varus or valgus deformities. The main issue with radial head fractures is decreased range of motion, particularly pronation and supination, rather than a visible deformity like in this case.

 

Option B. Lateral condyle humerus fracture: A lateral condyle fracture can lead to cubitus valgus, where the distal part of the arm deviates laterally, increasing the carrying angle. This is the opposite deformity to cubitus varus, which we see here. Non-union of lateral condyle fractures is the common cause of cubitus valgus, not cubitus varus.

 

Option C. Mid-shaft humerus fracture: A mid-shaft humerus fracture does not typically result in deformities like cubitus varus. While this fracture can result in functional issues, especially related to nerve injury (such as radial nerve palsy), it does not lead to elbow deformities unless complicated by additional elbow injury.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cubitus varus, a "gunstock" deformity, is a classic complication of malunited supracondylar humerus fractures in children, where the carrying angle is reduced, causing medial deviation of the arm.

questions.text: A patient present with Cotton wool skull. Most likely diagnosis is: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Paget's disease

 

  • Paget's disease of bone, also known as osteitis deformans, is a chronic disorder that can result in enlarged and misshapen bones. 
  • The condition is named after Sir James Paget, who first described it. 
  • The "cotton wool" appearance of the skull is a radiological hallmark of Paget's disease, resulting from the irregular thickening and softening of the bone. 
  • This appearance is due to a chaotic remodelling process where excessive bone resorption is followed by disorganized bone formation.
  • Thus, the skull X-ray reveal “cotton wool” or osteoporosis circumscripta, thickening of diploic area. Increasing Hat Size!

 

 

Additional Information:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Langerhans cell histiocyotsis: The radiological imaging of the skull in Langerhans cell histiocytosis shows solitary or multiple punched-out lytic lesions without sclerotic rim; double contour or beveled edge appearance due to asymmetrical involvement of the inner and outer; button sequestrum representing residual bone; and geographic skull. 

 

Option C. Hyperparathyroidism: Salt and pepper sign due to multiple tiny well-defined lucencies in the calvaria caused by resorption of trabecular bone in hyperparathyroidism. There is a loss of definition between the inner and outer tables of the skull; a ground-glass appearance; and spotty deossification.

 

Option D. Multiple myeloma: Radiographically, multiple myeloma appears as multiple, “punched-out”, sharply demarcated, purely lytic lesions without any surrounding reactive sclerosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The "cotton wool" appearance of the skull on radiographs is a classic sign of Paget's disease. 
  • This pattern results from the chaotic bone remodelling process characteristic of this condition.

questions.text: A child presents with left to right shunt and high output cardiac failure. The following is his MRI. What is the diagnosis?  (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Vein of Galen malformation

 

The MRI shown is suggestive of Vein of Galen Malformation (VOGM).

 

VOGM:

 

 

  • C/F: Newborn with high output cardiac failure with intracranial bruit
  • Type of A-V fistula
  • Doppler - Large midline vessel seen
  • MRI – Large flow void.
  • CT angiography – Giant vein of galen draining into straight sinus.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Dandy-walker malformation: This is a developmental malformation involving the cerebellum and the fluid spaces around it, characterized by an enlarged posterior cranial fossa. It is not associated with the imaging features seen in the provided MRI, which do not show the typical cerebellar and fourth ventricle abnormalities.

 

 

Option C. Pneumocephalus: This condition involves the presence of air within the cranial cavity, typically seen as areas of radiolucency (dark areas) on imaging, which are not present in the provided MRI.

 

Option D. Venous sinus thrombosis: This condition involves a clot within the dural venous sinuses, which would show different imaging characteristics, such as sinus obstruction or evidence of venous congestion, not observed here.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Vein of Galen malformation is a critical diagnosis to consider in infants presenting with signs of high-output cardiac failure, and it can be identified with specific imaging findings such as large flow voids on MRI indicative of abnormal vascular connections.

questions.text: Diagnose the condition shown in the following image.  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Chronic osteomyelitis

 

CHRONIC OSTEOMYELITIS

 

  • Chronic Osteomyelitis is a long-standing infection of the bone that typically results from bacteria, most commonly staphylococcus aureus.
  • It is characterized by persistent pain, swelling, warmth, and redness over the affected area.
  • The infection often leads to chronic discharge from a sinus tract or wound, and systemic symptoms may be less pronounced compared to acute infections.
  • On radiographs or MRI, chronic osteomyelitis may present as:
    • Bone Destruction: There can be areas of bone destruction or loss with possible formation of sequestra (dead bone) and involucrum (new bone formation surrounding the dead bone).
    • Sinus Tracts: Imaging may show draining sinus tracts or soft tissue swelling.
    • Cortical Erosion: There might be cortical erosion or irregularity.

 

 

  • Histopathology: Chronic osteomyelitis is characterized by the presence of chronic inflammatory cells, granulation tissue, and sometimes necrotic bone.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Ewing’s Sarcoma: Ewing’s Sarcoma is a malignant bone tumor typically found in children and young adults. It is one of the small round blue cell tumors. Patients usually present with localized pain, swelling, and possibly systemic symptoms like fever. The tumor often affects long bones or the pelvis.  On radiographs or MRI, Ewing’s sarcoma can present as a permeative lesion with ill-defined margins, an onion skin periosteal reaction. It is typically associated with an extensive soft tissue mass, an osteolytic lesion with or without calcifications. Histopathologically, it is characterized by small round blue cells with a characteristic "small round cell" appearance and is often confirmed with immunohistochemical staining and cytogenetic analysis (e.g., EWS-FLI1 fusion gene).

 

 

Option C. Osteosarcoma: Osteosarcoma is a malignant bone tumor that primarily affects adolescents and young adults. It is characterized by pain, swelling, and occasionally a palpable mass. It is commonly located around the knee or the metaphysis of long bones. On radiographs or MRI, osteosarcoma may present as mixed osteolytic and osteoblastic (sclerotic) lesions, formation of new bone perpendicular to the cortex due to the aggressive nature of the tumor lifting the periosteum, called as Codman’s triangle, and a soft tissue mass. Histopathologically, it shows pleomorphic osteoblasts producing malignant osteoid or bone matrix. Diagnosis is confirmed through biopsy and histological examination.

 

Codman’s triangle

 

Option D. Acute Osteomyelitis: Acute Osteomyelitis is a recent infection of the bone, usually caused by bacteria. Symptoms include rapid onset of severe pain, swelling, redness, and warmth over the affected area, often accompanied by systemic symptoms like fever and malaise. On radiographs or MRI, acute osteomyelitis may not show significant bone changes initially, but can later show bone marrow edema and possible periosteal reaction. As the condition progresses, there may be evidence of bone destruction, sequestra formation, or an abscess. Histopathologically, it is typically characterized by acute inflammatory changes with neutrophils and potentially abscess formation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Chronic Osteomyelitis is characterized by long-standing infection, typically with a chronic clinical course and imaging findings that reflect bone destruction and chronic inflammation.
  • The given image in the question shows sequestrum and involucrum in the lower end of femur, which are typically characteristic of chronic osteomyelitis.

questions.text: Which muscle is affected if the patient is unable to make an "OK" sign? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Flexor pollicis longus

 

The inability to make an "OK" sign is typically caused by a lesion of the anterior interosseous nerve, a branch of the median nerve. This nerve innervates three muscles, including the flexor pollicis longus (FPL), which is responsible for flexing the thumb. When the FPL is affected, the patient cannot flex the distal phalanx of the thumb, resulting in an inability to form the "OK" sign with their hand. The term "Kiloh-Nevin sign" is used to describe this clinical finding.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Abductor pollicis brevis: This muscle abducts the thumb and is innervated by the recurrent branch of the median nerve. It does not contribute to flexing the thumb for the "OK" sign.

 

Option C. Lumbricals: These muscles flex the metacarpophalangeal joints and extend the interphalangeal joints. They are not involved in making the "OK" sign.

 

Option D. Opponens pollicis: This muscle is involved in opposition of the thumb, allowing the thumb to touch the fingers, but it does not contribute directly to the flexion of the thumb required for the "OK" sign.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The flexor pollicis longus is essential for making the "OK" sign, and its impairment is a key clinical feature of anterior interosseous nerve damage.

questions.text: The Bragg peak effect is pronounced in: (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Proton

 

The Bragg peak effect is a phenomenon seen with proton therapy, where there is a sharp increase in radiation dose deposition at a specific depth, followed by a rapid decrease. This makes proton therapy particularly effective for targeting tumors with minimal damage to surrounding tissues.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. X-ray: X-rays do not exhibit the Bragg peak; they deposit radiation relatively uniformly along their path, leading to more widespread tissue damage.

 

Option C. Neutron: Neutrons, while used in certain types of radiation therapy, do not exhibit a Bragg peak. Their interactions are different, primarily involving nuclear reactions.

 

Option D. Electron: Electrons do have a distinct depth-dose distribution, which includes a peak dose at a certain depth, but it is not as sharp or pronounced as the Bragg peak seen with protons.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Proton beam therapy characteristics:

 

  • It has marked effect with increased depth in the soft tissues.
  • Bragg's peak is their peculiar feature.
  • Ideal agents for treating deep seated tumors.
  • Agent of choice for treatment of clival chordomas.

questions.text: A 10-year-old child presented with knee pain following a fall from the stairs. The physical and radiological evaluation revealed injury to the marked structure. Identify the structure. (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Tibial tuberosity

 

In this case, the injury is localized to the tibial tuberosity, a prominent bony projection on the anterior aspect of the tibia. The tibial tuberosity serves as the attachment point for the patellar ligament. Injuries to this region, especially in young, active individuals (often seen in adolescents), can be associated with Osgood-Schlatter disease, which is an osteochondritis of the tibial tuberosity. This condition is common in children and adolescents undergoing growth spurts and is characterized by knee pain, swelling, and tenderness at the tibial tuberosity following physical activity or trauma, such as a fall from stairs.

 

The patient in this question, a 10-year-old with knee pain after a fall, shows signs consistent with Osgood-Schlatter disease.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Medial tubercle: The medial tubercle refers to the medial part of the tibial plateau and is not directly related to the symptoms or the location of the injury in this case.

 

Option C. Gerdy's tubercle: Gerdy's tubercle is the insertion site for the iliotibial band on the lateral side of the tibia. The injury in the image and description does not involve Gerdy's tubercle, making this option incorrect.

 

Option D. Anterior intercondylar area: This area is located between the condyles of the tibia and is the site of cruciate ligament attachments. However, this is not the structure marked or injured in this scenario.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The tibial tuberosity is the site of attachment for the patellar ligament, and injuries to this region, particularly in young individuals, can result in conditions such as Osgood-Schlatter disease, characterized by pain at the site, especially following physical activity or trauma.

questions.text: Sprengel’s deformity associated with all except: (INICET Nov 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Dextrocardia

 

SPRENGEL’S DEFORMITY

 

  • It consists of permanent elevation of the shoulder girdle due to developmental defect.
  • The scapula is smaller in its vertical diameter and appears broad. It lies high in position.

 

 

  • Para scapular muscles are composed of imperfectly developed muscle fibers or fibrous tissue.
  • From the superior angle of scapula a sheet or band-like structure composed of fibrous tissue cartilage or bone extends upwards to attach to the transverse process of several cervical vertebrae known as Omovertebral bar.

 

 

  • It is associated with Klippel-Feil Syndrome/Scoliosis/Spina bifida (Diastematomyelia)/Cervical rib.
  • Clinical Feature: Shoulder and the scapula at a higher level than the opposite one, restriction of shoulder movement.
  • Treatment: There is no definitive treatment available. Surgery (Woodward procedure) is done for cosmetic reasons only.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Dextrocardia is rarely associated with Sprengel’s Deformity.

questions.text: A construction worker sustained a head injury from a hammer falling on his head. The CT scan image is shown as below. What is the diagnosis ?(FMGE 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Depressed skull fracture

 

  • The provided X-ray and CT image specifically shows the inward depression of the skull, which confirms the diagnosis of a depressed skull fracture. This condition requires urgent medical evaluation to assess for underlying brain injury and possible surgical intervention to correct the skull deformity and reduce the risk of complications like brain compression or infection.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Epidural Hematoma: Typically appears as a biconvex (lens-shaped) mass between the skull and the dura mater on imaging. It is generally associated with arterial bleeding and is a neurosurgical emergency.

 

Option B. Concussion: A form of mild traumatic brain injury (TBI) usually caused by a blow to the head. It does not typically show up on a CT scan and is diagnosed based on clinical symptoms rather than imaging findings.

 

Option D. Subarachnoid Hemorrhage: This would appear as areas of increased density within the subarachnoid space on a CT scan, typically caused by trauma or ruptured aneurysms. It doesn’t present with structural deformity of the skull as seen in the image.

 

Educational objective :

 

  • Depressed Skull Fracture is visible on a CT scan as parts of the skull bone being pushed inward toward the brain. It's often caused by direct impact, such as being hit with a hammer, and can pose a risk of brain injury depending on the depth and location of the depression.

questions.text: A 75-year-old female had a fall and had intertrochanteric fracture. This is due to:(AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Osteoporosis

 

OSTEOPOROSIS (V > H > C)

 

  • Osteoporosis is reduction in bone mass (density) i.e., there is quantitative decrease of units of bone formation but each unit has qualitatively normal configuration.
  • So, osteoporosis characteristically has normal calcium, phosphate and alkaline phosphatase levels.
  • Bone Mineral Density is measured by DEXA (Dual Emission X-ray Absorptiometry) Scan and it is matched to DEXA scan of 30-year-old individual of the same sex and T score is calculated.

 

 

  • Etiology of Osteoporosis:

 

 

  • Imaging:
    • Radiological features are loss of vertical height of vertebrae (collapse) and codfish appearance (concave superior and inferior surfaces) of vertebrae.
    • Singh’s Index is used for osteoporosis grading.
  • Treatment: Drugs used in osteoporosis are:
    1. Inhibit resorption: Bisphosphonates (drug of choice), Denosumab, calcitonin, estrogen, SERMS, gallium nitrate.
    2. Stimulate formation: Teriparatide (PTH analogue), calcium, calcitriol, fluorides.
    3. Both actions: Strontium ranelate

 

 

Codfish Vertebrae (Osteoporosis/Osteomalacia)

 

Note: Intertrochanteric hip fractures are the most commonly occurring fractures in the elderly osteoporotic population.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Osteopetrosis. This disease is commonly seen in children. It is a diaphyseal dysplasia characterized by failure of bone resorption due to functional deficiency of osteoclast. Due to functional deficiency of osteoclasts, calcified chondroid (cartilage) and primitive woven bone persists down into metaphysis and diaphysis, leading to osteosclerosis and increased brittleness of bones (marble bone disease). Autosomal dominant osteopetrosis is diagnosed in adult asymptomatic patients. It may present with mild anemia, pathological fractures premature osteoarthritis, and rarely osteomyelitis of mandible. Autosomal recessive malignant (congenital) osteopetrosis clinically presents at birth or in early infancy because of obliteration of marrow cavity by bony overgrowth resulting in inability of bone marrow to participate in hematopoiesis. Pancytopenia develops resulting in abnormal bleeding, easy bruising, progressive anemia, and failure to thrive. Laboratory parameters are serum calcium low, serum PTH high, serum phosphate low and serum ALP high. Radiological hallmark is increased radiopacity of bones. There is no distinction between cortical and cancellous bone, because intramedullary canal is filled with bone. Endobones (os in os or bone within bone appearance) and rugger jersey spine are seen on radiographs. Treatment is bone marrow transplant.

 

 

Option C. Paget’s disease. It is characterized by excessive disorganized bone turnover, that encompasses excessive osteoclastic activity initially followed by disorganized excessive new bone formation. Osteoclast appears larger and irregular whereas osteoblast are relatively normal. The new bone formed is abnormal, very vascular and larger (deforms and fractures) than preexisting bone, which leads to cortical widening and deformity. The diagnostic histological feature of Paget's disease is irregular area of lamellar bone fitting together like a jigsaw with randomly distributed cement lines. Initial osteolytic phase involves prominent bone resorption and marked hypervascularization (Radiologically seen as advancing lytic wedge or blade of grass lesion). 2nd phase of active bone formation and resorption replaces normal lamellar bone with structurally weak woven bone that bend, bow and fracture easily. In 3rd sclerotic (burnt out) phase, bone resorption declines progressively and leads to hard, dense, less vascular pagetic or mosaic bone. Most people are asymptomatic. The sites most commonly involved are pelvis, tibia, followed by skull, spine, clavicle and femur. It affects men (> 50 years) more commonly. Pain is most common presenting symptom. Limb looks bent and feels thick, and skin is unduly warm due to high vascularity.

 

 

Blade of grass

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Hip fractures are most commonly seen in elderly females due to osteoporosis.

questions.text: Which of the following tests are used for the evaluation of scoliosis?(AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Bending forward

 

SCOLIOSIS

 

  • Scoliosis is characterized by lateral curvature of the spine associated with rotation of the involved vertebrae and classified by its anatomic location, in either the thoracic or lumbar spine, with rare involvement of the cervical spine.
  • Clinical Findings:
    • Scoliosis in adolescents does not typically cause significant pain.
    • If a patient has significant pain, she/he should be evaluated to rule out the possibility of some other disorder such as infection or tumor.
    • Deformity of the rib cage and asymmetry of the waistline are clinically evident for curvatures of 30 degrees or more.
    • Lesser curves may be detected through a forward bending test (Adam’s test), which is designed to detect early abnormalities of rotation that may not be apparent when the patient is standing erect.
    • Structural curve becomes more prominent on forward bending as opposed to postural scoliosis.
    • Rotation of the spine may be measured with a scoliometer.
    • Rotation is associated with a marked rib hump as the lateral curvature increases in severity.
       
  • Imaging:
    • Radiographs taken of the entire spine in the standing position in both the posterior anterior (PA) and lateral planes are the most valuable for diagnosis.
    • Usually, a primary curve is evident with compensatory curvature to balance the body.
       
  • Treatment:
    • Treatment of scoliosis depends on the curve magnitude, skeletal maturity, and risk of progression.
    • Specific management is dependent on the Cobb angle, measured on a standing PA X-ray of the spine.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Scoliosis curve evaluation is done by forward bending test/Adam’s test.
  • A structural scoliotic curve becomes more prominent on forward bending while the postural curve disappears.

questions.text: Which movement of the hip is being demonstrated by the examiner in the following diagram?(AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Internal rotation

 

HIP MOVEMENTS

 

  • The given image shows the internal rotation movement of the hip.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. External rotation.

 

 

Option C. Adduction.

 

 

Option D. Abduction.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The given image shows internal rotation of hip.

questions.text: Identify the image. (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Fluoroscopy

 

The image provided is a still from a video fluoroscopy study, which is essentially a continuous X-ray video that allows the visualization of dynamic processes in real time, such as swallowing. This technique is used for examining the movement of the pharynx and esophagus. Although the image might appear to be from a barium swallow study, the key distinguishing factor is that it shows only the pharynx, which aligns more with a fluoroscopy study rather than a traditional barium swallow.

 

In a barium swallow, the entire esophagus is visualized, whereas fluoroscopy focuses more on the pharyngeal phase of swallowing. Therefore, even though both fluoroscopy and barium swallow are correct interpretations of the image, fluoroscopy is the more precise answer since it captures the pharyngeal motion observed in the image.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Barium swallow: A barium swallow involves the patient swallowing barium to coat the esophagus, making it visible on X-rays. However, this image specifically shows the pharyngeal phase, which is more consistent with fluoroscopy rather than a complete barium swallow study.

 

Option C. Acid ingestion: Acid ingestion refers to the damage to the esophagus or stomach lining due to acid, which would present differently on imaging. This condition does not correspond to the observed fluoroscopy of swallowing.

 

Option D. Alkali ingestion: Similar to acid ingestion, alkali ingestion would show chemical burns or strictures but would not be directly visualized in a swallowing motion study like fluoroscopy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Fluoroscopy is a dynamic X-ray imaging technique used to visualize the motion of the pharynx and esophagus during swallowing. It provides real-time assessment, unlike a static barium swallow.

questions.text: The longitudinal growth of the bone is affected by fracture of which region of the bone? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Epiphyseal plate

 

The epiphyseal plate, also known as the growth plate or physis, is responsible for the longitudinal growth of long bones in children and adolescents. It consists primarily of cartilage, made up of type II collagen, which progressively ossifies to contribute to the bone's lengthening. This growth plate remains active until it closes after puberty, marking the end of the bone's longitudinal growth. Any fracture affecting this area, such as a Salter-Harris fracture, can disrupt this growth process, potentially leading to growth disturbances or deformities.

 

The other regions of the bone (diaphysis, epiphysis, and metaphysis) are involved in different processes, but they do not directly influence the longitudinal growth as the epiphyseal plate does.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Diaphysis: This is the shaft of the long bone, primarily involved in providing structural support and is not directly responsible for longitudinal growth. Fractures in the diaphysis do not affect the bone's length.

 

Option B. Epiphysis: The epiphysis is the rounded end of the long bone, which forms the joint surface. It plays a role in articulating with adjacent bones and, while important for bone structure, it does not contribute directly to longitudinal growth.

 

Option D. Metaphysis: This is the wide portion of a long bone between the epiphysis and the diaphysis. It is highly vascular and is a common site for bone tumors and infections but is not responsible for the longitudinal growth of the bone.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The epiphyseal plate is the region of the bone responsible for longitudinal growth, and fractures affecting this area can have significant implications on the bone's growth and development.

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy presents with bitemporal hemianopia. CT is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?(NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Craniopharyngioma

 

A calcified lesion in the suprasellar region suggests craniopharyngioma. It is derived from Rathke's pouch.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A: Pituitary adenomas are seen in the sellar region in adults. Macroadenomas are seen as snowman or figure of eight appearance.

 

Option B: Meningioma is a supratentorial tumor, mainly in the parasagittal region. A classical Dural tail is seen.

 

Option D: Oligodendroglioma is exclusively found in the cerebral hemispheres, most commonly in the frontal lobes. Up to 90% of oligodendrogliomas contain visible calcification on CT.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Craniopharyngioma should be considered in young patients presenting with symptoms of visual field loss and a calcified suprasellar mass on imaging. This tumor's characteristic location and calcification are key diagnostic clues.

 

Reference– Grainger & Allison’s Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, Second Edition, Page No 742

questions.text: A 21-year-old male presented in clinic with low back pain & stiffness since 2 months. Modified Schober's test done was positive. An X-ray was done as shown in the image. Most likely diagnosis is:(AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Ankylosing spondylitis

 

ANKYLOSING SPONDYLITIS

 

  • Also known as Marie-Strumpell or Bechterew’s disease.
    • It is a chronic inflammatory disease affecting the spine and sacroiliac joints.
    • HLA B27 is positive in 90% patients.
    • Sacroiliitis is the earliest manifestation with features of both enthesitis & synovitis.
    • Clinical Presentation:
      • It is most commonly seen in young males aged 15 - 25 years.
      • Most common symptom is dull backache, insidious in onset, associated with morning stiffness and improves with activity.
      • Hip and shoulder joint arthritis may occur. Peripheral joints may also be involved in some.
      • Anterior uveitis is the most common extra-articular manifestation.
  • Diagnostic Criteria: Modified New York Criterion:
    • Essential criteria is definite radiographic sacroiliitis
    • Supporting criteria: one of these three:
      • Inflammatory back pain
      • Limited chest expansion (<5 cm at 4th ICS) {not a reliable criterion in elderly because of pulmonary disorders}
      • Limited lumbar spine motion in both sagittal and frontal plane (Schober test/Modified Schober test).
    • Inflammatory back pain is classified if 4/5 are present
      1. Pain for > 3 months
      2. <40 years age
      3. Insidious onset
      4. Pain improves with exercise
      5. Pain at night
  • Spine radiograph shows:
    • Haziness of sacroiliac (SI) joint margins is the earliest change.
    • Later on, SI joints show irregular subchondral erosions in, sclerotic articular margins, joint space widening and eventually bony ankylosis.
    • Calcification of supraspinous & interspinous ligaments (Dagger sign) and that of sacroiliac and sacrotuberous ligaments.

 

 

Dagger sign

 

  • Enthesopathy: Calcification at the attachment of muscles, tendons & ligaments.
  • Trolley/Tram-track sign: Three linear radiopaque lines due to ligament calcification.
  • Squaring of vertebra, loss of lumbar lordosis and bridging osteophytes (syndesmophytes) are seen.

 

 

Trolley track sign

 

  • Bamboo spine  appearance due to syndesmophytes.

 

 

Bamboo spine

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Osteoporosis. Osteoporosis is reduction in bone mass (density) i.e. there is quantitative decrease of units of bone formation but each unit has qualitatively normal configuration. So, osteoporosis characteristically has normal calcium, phosphate and alkaline phoshatase levels. Bone Mineral Density is measured by DEXA (Dual Emission X-ray Absorptiometry) Scan and it is matched to Dexa scan of 30 year old individual and T score is calculated. WHO classification of values in a DEXA scan are T score 0 to –1 is normal, T score –1 to –2.5 is osteopenia, and T score less than –2.5 is osteoporosis. The patient is usually asymptomatic until a vertebral fracture occurs. The x-ray of the spine shows codfish vertebrae.

 

 

Option C. PIVD. Lumbar Disc Herniation is a very common cause of low back pain and unilateral leg pain, known as radiculopathy. The patient usually presents with decreased lumbar movement, paraspinal muscle spasm. The provocative tests like straight leg raise is positive. The x-ray shows decreased space between the affected vertebrae due to disc prolapse.

 

 

Option D. Osteoarthritis. Spine osteoarthritis is the presence of disc degeneration and osteophyte formation. The typical presentation of patients with symptomatic osteoarthritis of the spine is pain, stiffness, and motion restriction, which is commonly accompanied by referred pain. The lumbar spine provides pain located in the buttock and thigh region. Lumbar spine osteoarthritis can be associated with radicular pain above the knee.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The given image in the question shows the bamboo spine appearance which is characteristic of ankylosing spondylitis.
  • Out of the diagnostic criterias for ankylosing spondylitis, one of the criteria is the positive modified Schober’s test i.e., limited lumbar spine movement in saggital and frontal planes.

questions.text: Haglund’s deformity is seen in which joint?(AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Ankle

 

HAGLUND DEFORMITY

 

  • Haglund deformity is prominent Calcaneal tuberosity and overlying bursitis (retro-calcaneal).
  • It is a bony enlargement formed at posterosuperior aspect of calcaneum along with retrocalcaneal bursitis.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Haglund deformity is seen at the ankle joint.

questions.text: A female present with pain and swelling over multiple peripheral small joints and deformity as shown below. What is the likely diagnosis?(NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Rheumatoid Arthritis

 

  • The image shows swan neck deformity seen in RA.
  • Characteristic Deformities of Hand and Foot In RA:

 

 

 

 

Finger deformities in RA

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Psoriatic arthropathy. Five patterns of joint involvement are seen: Arthritis of DIP joint, Asymmetrical oligoarthritis, Symmetrical polyarthritis, Axial involvement (spine and sacroiliac joint), and Arthritis mutilans. Nail changes occurs in 90% patients of psoriatic arthritis. Dactylitis, enthesitis and tenosynovitis are also common Shortening of digitis (telescoping), because of underlying osteolysis is characteristic of psoriatic arthritis. Fibrous and bony ankylosis of small joints (greater tendency than RA). Almost any peripheral joint can be involved. Radiological Features includes classical pencil cup deformity of DIP joints.

 

 

Pencil-in-cup deformity

 

Option C. Osteoarthritis. Osteoarthritis characteristically involves distal interphalangeal joint (Heberden’s node), proximal interphalangeal joint (Bouchard’s node), 1st carpometacarpal joint (base of thumb) of hand. Sparing of wrist and MCP is a feature of Osteoarthritis.

 

 

Option D. Scleroderma. Scleroderma is a severe CTD characterized by vascular, immune and fibrotic changes in the skin and internal organs. While tethering of the skin is the clinical hallmark of SSc, many patients develop musculoskeletal symptoms also. Manifestations may include rheumatic complaints ranging from arthralgias to frank arthritis, contractures and tendon friction rubs. Articular involvement contributes to disability and impaired quality of life. All joints may be affected, although the fingers (in particular the MCP and PIP joints), wrists and ankles predominate. As the disease progresses, there is tethering and contracture of the joints with impairment of movement and function.

 

 

Calcinosis and contracture of joints

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The image in the question shows swan neck deformity, which is characteristic of Rheumatoid Arthritis.

questions.text: Hyperextension at MCP joint and flexion at IP joint occurs due to involvement of which muscle?(NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Lumbricals and interossei

 

  • The Lumbricals (+ interossei) paralysis causes claw hand (MCP hyperextension and IP joint flexion).

 

 

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Hyperextension of the MCP joint and flexion of the IP joint is seen in the claw hand deformity due to weakness of the intrinsic muscles of the hand i.e., the lumbricals and the interossei.

choices.text: Pain in both active and passive movements

questions.text: Non-articular bone pain is differentiated from articular bone pain by:(NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Pain in only active movements

 

ARTICULAR VS NON-ARTICULAR PAIN

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Non-articular pain occurs only during active movements. When both active and passive range of movements are painful, it is due to articular pain.

questions.text: What is the diagnosis based on the given image? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Unicornuate uterus

 

The given image shows the HSG of a Unicornuate uterus. The endometrial cavity forms a fusiform (banana type) shape, tapering at the apex and draining into a single fallopian tube. The uterus is generally shifted off the midline.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Uterus didelphys is a type of Müllerian duct anomaly where there is a complete duplication of uterine horns as well as duplication of the cervix, with no communication between them.

 

 

Option B. Bicornuate uterus is due to incomplete fusion of the mullerian ducts and is characterized by the presence of a cleft in the external contour of the uterine fundus.

 

 

Option C. Septate uterus is the result of partial or complete failure of resorption of the uterovaginal septum after fusion of the paramesonephric ducts.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Unicornuate uterus is identified on HSG by a fusiform shape and a single fallopian tube connection, often displaced from the midline, indicating unilateral Müllerian duct development.

questions.text: Which type of translocation is seen in diaphyseal tumor with small blue round cells? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) T11, 22

 

The question refers to Ewing's sarcoma, a type of malignant tumor that typically affects the diaphysis (shaft) of long bones, particularly in children and young adults. The tumor is characterized by small, round, blue cells when viewed under a microscope. A hallmark of Ewing's sarcoma is the t(11;22) translocation, which fuses the EWSR1 gene on chromosome 22 with the FLI1 gene on chromosome 11. This translocation results in the production of an abnormal protein that drives the cancer.

 

This translocation, t(11;22), is highly specific for Ewing's sarcoma and is used as a diagnostic marker.

 

Mic 2 (CD99) – Most specific marker for Ewing’s sarcoma

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. EWSR1, WT1: This combination is incorrect for Ewing's sarcoma. While EWSR1 is involved, WT1 is a gene associated with Wilms' tumor, a kidney cancer, and is not involved in Ewing's sarcoma.

 

Option C. T15,17: This translocation is characteristic of acute promyelocytic leukemia (APL), not Ewing's sarcoma. The fusion of the PML and RARA genes occurs in APL.

 

Option D. T2,13: This translocation is associated with alveolar rhabdomyosarcoma, another type of soft tissue tumor, but not with Ewing's sarcoma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The t(11;22) translocation is characteristic of Ewing's sarcoma, a diaphyseal tumor with small, round, blue cells, making it a crucial genetic marker for diagnosis.

questions.text: A football player had a twisting injury of the knee with no clinical bony injury. Which test is being performed here? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Lachman’s test

 

The image shows the examiner performing a test where the knee is placed in 20 to 30 degrees of flexion and the tibia is pulled anteriorly. This describes the Lachman’s test, which is used to assess the integrity of the anterior cruciate ligament (ACL).

 

  • The Lachman’s test is preferred over the anterior drawer test for diagnosing ACL injuries because it can be performed with the knee in slight flexion, which isolates the ACL and reduces the influence of other structures. A positive Lachman’s test, indicated by increased anterior movement of the tibia relative to the femur, suggests an ACL tear.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Anterior drawer test: The anterior drawer test is also used to assess ACL injuries but differs from the Lachman’s test in that the knee is flexed at 90 degrees. In the anterior drawer test, the examiner pulls the tibia forward while stabilizing the leg, but this test can be less sensitive than the Lachman’s test in acute injuries.

 

Option C. McMurray’s test: McMurray’s test is used to evaluate meniscal injuries, not ligamentous injuries. It involves flexing the knee and applying rotational forces to check for a meniscal tear. It is done with the knee in 90 degrees of flexion and involves listening for clicking or popping sounds in the meniscus.

 

Option D. Posterior drawer test: The posterior drawer test is used to assess the integrity of the posterior cruciate ligament (PCL). It is performed with the knee at 90 degrees of flexion, and the examiner pushes the tibia backward. This is not the test being performed in the image, as the tibia is being pulled anteriorly.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Lachman’s test is the most reliable physical exam maneuver for diagnosing ACL tears, performed with the knee in 20-30 degrees of flexion.

questions.text: What is the preferred diagnostic investigation for a patient presenting with this finding? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Duplex

 

  • This combines traditional ultrasound and Doppler technology to assess blood flow and the structure of blood vessels. It's the standard, first-line option for diagnosing venous insufficiency and varicose veins because it visualizes both the blood flow and the structure of the leg veins.
  • For a patient presenting with the finding shown in the image, which appears to be significant venous insufficiency or varicosities in the legs, a Duplex ultrasound is indeed the preferred diagnostic tool.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Plethysmography: This test measures changes in volume within an organ or whole limb, typically used to detect abnormalities in venous filling and emptying, indicating deep vein thrombosis or chronic venous insufficiency. While useful, it doesn’t provide direct imaging of the veins.

 

Option B. MRI (Magnetic Resonance Imaging): While MRI can be used to assess veins and other vascular structures, it's generally not the first choice for examining veins in cases of suspected varicose veins due to cost and availability.

 

Option D. CT (Computed Tomography): Though CT scans provide detailed images, they are typically more useful for diagnosing issues within abdominal organs, detecting blood clots in lungs (pulmonary embolisms), or for complex vascular assessments that might require a three-dimensional view.

 

Educational Objective :

 

  • Duplex ultrasound is highly effective for diagnosing conditions affecting the blood vessels, like venous insufficiency, because it can directly visualize both the anatomy of the blood vessels and the movement of blood through them.

questions.text: Identify the given sign:(NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Popeye sign

 

  • This image shows typical finding on physical examination, which is caused by bulging of the biceps muscle belly after rupture of the biceps tendon, known as Popeye sign or Popeye deformity.
  • The Popeye is a cartoon character with bulging muscles, hence its name.

 

POPEYE SIGN

 

  • Etiology:
    • Due to sudden eccentric biomechanical load is applied with the forearm flexed and supinated, which can cause the rupture of either the proximal or the distal tendon junctions.
       
  • Risk factors: 
    • Older age
    • Smoking habit
    • Usage of certain drugs (corticosteroids, statins).
    • Shoulder overuse (sports or work-related activities).

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Inverted champagne bottle sign. This sign is seen in Lipodermatosclerosis, also referred to as sclerosing panniculitis or hypodermitis sclerodermaformis, which is a persistent inflammatory disorder characterized by the development of subcutaneous fibrosis and induration of the skin of the lower extremities. The chronic phase of lipodermatosclerosis is characterized by well-defined, circumferential, thick, darkly pigmented, non-tender plaques. These plaques are described as having a firm, “woody” induration, and the sclerotic change with circumferential narrowing of the lower leg and concurrent proximal and distal edema, that produces the classic “inverted champagne bottle” appearance of the lower extremity. The rounded cork of the champagne bottle is symbolic of the edematous foot, the central fibrosis around the ankle represents the neck, and the bottle's body embodies the lymphedema proximal to the area of constriction.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The image shown in the question is called Popeye Sign, which is visible on elbow flexion due to bicipital tendonitis.

questions.text: Name the investigation shown in the given image?(NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Conventional HSG

 

Hysterosalpingography

 

  • Hysterosalpingography is the fluoroscopic examination commonly used in the investigations of infertility to assess uterine morphology and tubal patency.
  • The best time to investigate is during the 6th to 10th day of menstrual cycle (not to be done during menstruation; risk of damage to undiagnosed pregnancy after 10th day)
  • A radiopaque dye is injected through the Leech-Wilkinson or Rubin's cannula, or Foley's catheter into the uterine cavity under direct vision with fluoroscopic screen.
  • If the tubes are patent, the medium is usually adequate to exit through the abdominal ostia and smear the adjacent bowel.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. MR HSG: Involves the use of magnetic resonance imaging to view the uterine cavity and fallopian tubes, not compatible with the use of traditional radiopaque dyes and does not involve real-time fluoroscopy.

 

Option B. CT HSG: Utilizes computed tomography, which is less common and not shown in the image due to the distinct fluoroscopic appearance of conventional HSG.

 

Option D. USG HSG: Ultrasound HSG, also known as sonohysterography, uses ultrasound technology to evaluate the uterus and fallopian tubes, which would not display the classic radiopaque dye pattern seen in the image.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Conventional HSG is a critical diagnostic tool in the assessment of uterine structure and tubal patency, using a radiopaque dye visualized with fluoroscopy, particularly useful in the workup of infertility.

questions.text: What is the diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Chronic pancreatitis

 

Chronic pancreatitis is characterized by the presence of calcifications along the pancreas, which is a hallmark sign visible on imaging. The X-ray shows calcification along the pancreas, which is indicative of chronic inflammation and fibrosis due to ongoing damage to the pancreatic tissue. These calcifications are a classic sign of chronic pancreatitis and help differentiate it from other conditions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Wolman disease: Wolman disease is a rare genetic disorder characterized by calcifications in the adrenal glands due to a deficiency in lysosomal acid lipase. The calcifications in Wolman disease appear near the adrenal glands, which are located superiorly to the kidneys, rather than along the pancreas.

 

Option C. Acute pancreatitis: Acute pancreatitis typically presents with inflammation of the pancreas but does not usually involve calcification. Acute cases are seen with other signs of inflammation like fluid collections but not chronic calcifications.

 

Option D. TB Tuberculosis: Tuberculosis rarely shows calcification on a plain abdominal X-ray unless there is involvement of specific abdominal lymph nodes or organ involvement like the adrenal glands. Pancreatic calcification is not a typical feature of TB.

 

Educational Objective:


Chronic pancreatitis is characterized by pancreatic calcifications on imaging, which are absent in acute pancreatitis and other conditions like Wolman disease or TB.

questions.text: A patient who used to work out regularly at the gym gradually developed pain in the hip which is aggravated while squatting. He gives history of regular steroid and creatine use over last six months. There is flattening of femoral head and subchondral cysts were seen on X-ray. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. AVN of hip

 

AVASCULAR NECROSIS

 

  • Avascular necrosis (AVN) is the cellular death of components of bone due to impaired blood supply.
  • It affects anterolateral aspect of femoral head.
  • Etiopathogenesis: Idiopathic (most common) – called as Chandeliers disease.
  • Causes of AVN of Femoral Head:

 

 

  • Clinical Features:
    • Age 20-50 years with slight male preponderance (Young Male).
    • Bilateral in 50% of idiopathic cases, and 80% of steroid induced cases.
    • Decreased range of motion especially internal rotation followed by abduction.
    • This is a characteristic feature of any disease in which femoral head shape is altered -  abduction and internal rotation is reduced (also seen in Perthes, Slipped Capital Femoral Epiphysis).
    • A characteristic sign is a tendency for hip to twist into external rotation during passive flexion; this corresponds to the ‘Sectoral sign’ in which, with the hip extended, internal rotation is almost full but with hip flexed it is grossly restricted, it is due to a sector of femoral head being involved in AVN.
    • X-rays shows Sclerosed area – Area of necrosis; Crescent sign – Crescentric defect in subchondral area.
  • MRI is the investigation of choice – Double line sign is seen.
    • T1 – AVN: Reduced intensity or irregular outline of head.
    • T2 – high signal intensity called as double line sign.

 

 

  • Treatment:
    • Early stages: protected weight-bearing.
    • Pre-collapse stage: Core decompression to decrease intraosseous pressure in femoral head (Intraosseous pressure Normal 10-20 mm Hg, it is 3-4 times in AVN).  Drill holes are made in femoral head. This procedure also opens the channels for vascular ingrowths and it is also supplemented with bone grafting (Vascular or nonvascular) or electrical stimulation or bone morphogenic proteins.
    • Muscle Pedicle graft: Quadratus femoris (Meyers graft)/Tensor fascia lata graft (Joshi’s graft) can be fixed in femoral head to augment vascularity.
    • Rotational osteotomy: To get the intact part of femoral head in acetabulum weight-bearing area (anterolateral aspect of femur head) this is an extensive procedure requiring vascular repair along with it.
    • Arthritis/Collapse of femoral head: Total hip replacement one of the very commonly done procedure as most patients present at stage of arthritis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. TB of hip. Osteoarticular TB is secondary to primary pathology in lungs, lymph nodes or viscera. Through the hematogenous route, the bacteria reach either to synovium or bone. The bacteria may lodge first in the epiphyseal or metaphyseal region of the bones like head or neck of femur, greater trochanter or acetabulum. Pain in the hip, limp, restriction of movements is present in almost all the cases.

 

 

 

Wandering acetabulum seen in stage 4 of hip TB

 

Option C. Fracture neck of femur. Femoral neck fractures are associated with low energy falls in the elderly.
