In younger patients, the cause is usually high-energy trauma such as motor vehicle accidents. Risk factors for femoral neck fractures include female gender, decreased mobility, and low bone density. The patient will complain of pain with a decreased range of motion of the hip. In undisplaced fractures, there may be no deformity. However, displaced fractures may present with a shortened and externally rotated lower limb.

 

 

Option D. Osteomalacia. Osteomalacia is a disorder of “bone softening” in adults that is due to prolonged deficiency of vitamin D. This deficiency results in abnormal osteoid mineralization. Symptoms are non-specific and may include proximal muscle weakness and wasting, myalgias and arthralgias, muscle spasms, aching bone pain aggravated by activity and weight-bearing. Radiographic findings may include Looser zones or pseudofractures, a classic finding in osteomalacia. They may represent poorly repaired fractures and are visible as transverse lucencies perpendicular to the osseous cortex. They typically occur bilaterally and symmetrically at the femoral necks, shafts, pubic and ischial rami.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Pain in the hip aggravated while squatting with history of regular use of steroid over last six months, flattening of femoral head and presence of subchondral cysts on X-ray are suggestive of AVN of the hip.

choices.text: a, b, c, d are correct

questions.text:
Evaluate the following statements with respect to CTEV.(AIIMS NOV 2019)

 

  1. 50% cases are in males and are bilateral
  2. Forefoot is adducted and supinated
  3. With Ponsetti technique, correction is up to 90%
  4. Equinus should be corrected first
questions.solution:
Ans. A. a, b, c are correct

 

  • CTEV is a congenital foot deformity characterized by several components:

    • Cavus: High arch

    • Adduction: Forefoot turned inward

    • Supination: Sole of the foot turned inward

    • Equinus: Plantarflexion 

    • Varus: Inversion of the heel

 

a. 50% cases are in males and are bilateral: 

 

  • Clubfoot is more common in males than females. The ratio is roughly 2:1. So, more than 50% of cases are in males.

  • Approximately 50% of all clubfoot cases occur in both feet (bilateral).

 

b. Forefoot is adducted and supinated:

 

  • This statement is correct. 

  • As mentioned earlier, forefoot adduction and supination are key components of the clubfoot deformity.

 

c. With Ponsetti technique, correction is up to 90%:

 

  • This statement is considered correct. 

  • The Ponseti method, a non-surgical treatment involving serial casting, has very high success rates, often reported around 90% or even higher when followed properly.

 

Other Option:

 

d. Equinus should be corrected first:

 

  • This statement is incorrect. 

  • The Ponseti method typically follows a specific sequence of correction:

    1. Cavus: Addressing the high arch first.

    2. Adduction and Supination: Correcting the inward turning of the forefoot.

    3. Varus: Correcting the inversion of the heel.

    4. Equinus: Addressing the plantarflexion of the foot, often as the final step.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In CTEV, male children are more affected than females. 

  • 50% of cases of CTEV have bilateral lower limb involvement. 

  • There is forefoot adduction and supination in cases of CTEV. 

  • Ponseti method of conservative treatment gives correction of up to 90%. 

 

Equinus deformity is corrected at last, following the C-A-V-E sequence.

questions.text: Involvement of PIP, DIP and 1st CMC with sparing of wrist and MCP is seen in: (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Osteoarthritis

 

  • Osteoarthritis characteristically involves distal interphalangeal joint (Heberden’s node), proximal interphalangeal joint (Bouchard’s node), 1st carpometacarpal joint (base of thumb) of hand.

 

 

  • Sparing of wrist and MCP is a feature of Osteoarthritis.
  • Rheumatoid Arthritis spares DIP and involves PIP, MCP and Wrist.
  • Diseases And Usual Joints Affected:

 

 

  • Characteristic Joint involvement in HANDS in various Arthritis:

 

 

 

 

The hand (to diagnose arthritis)

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Rheumatoid arthritis. Commonly Involved Joints (14 joints are used for diagnosis according to 1987 criterion – Right or left side) are Wrist joint, Metacarpophalangeal (MCP) joint, Proximal interphalangeal (PIP) joint, Elbow joint, Knee joint, Ankle joint, and Metatarsophalangeal joint. Less Commonly Involved joints are Upper cervical spine (facet joint) with Atlantoaxial subluxation, Hip joint, Temporomandibular joint, Subtalar and forefoot joints. Usually, DIP is not involved but is involved when swan neck and boutonniere deformity develops. The involvement in late stages is due to the pull of tendons/soft tissues in these deformities. Lumbar Spine is Usually Spared in RA.

 

 

 

Option B. Psoriatic arthropathy. Five patterns of joint involvement are seen: Arthritis of DIP joint, Asymmetrical oligoarthritis, Symmetrical polyarthritis, Axial involvement (spine and sacroiliac joint), and Arthritis mutilans. Nail changes occurs in 90% patients of psoriatic arthritis. Dactylitis, enthesitis and tenosynovitis are also common Shortening of digitis (telescoping), because of underlying osteolysis is characteristic of psoriatic arthritis. Fibrous and bony ankylosis of small joints (greater tendency than RA). Almost any peripheral joint can be involved. Radiological Features includes classical pencil cup deformity of DIP joints.

 

 

Pencil-in-cup deformity

 

Option D. Jaccoud arthropathy. It typically affects MCP joints but can also affect PIP joints of the hand, wrist joint and knee joint. It is a deforming non-erosive arthropathy characterized by ulnar deviation of 2nd-5th fingers with MCP joint subluxation.

 

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Involvement of PIP, DIP and 1st CMC with sparing of wrist and MCP is seen in osteoarthritis.

questions.text: A 56-year-old woman presented with chronic low back pain. CT scan of the lower back showed the following. Diagnose the condition CT scan image shown? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Spondylolisthesis

 
Spondylolisthesis refers to the slipping or displacement of one vertebra over another. It is commonly caused by a defect or fracture in the pars interarticularis, a part of the vertebra, which leads to instability in the spine. This condition is often visualized as a "slip" on X-rays or CT scans. A characteristic sign is the "beheaded dog" or "Scottish terrier sign," where the neck of the dog (representing the pars interarticularis) appears broken, indicating spondylolysis, which can lead to spondylolisthesis. This vertebral slippage is most commonly observed between the L5 and S1 vertebrae.

 

In this case, the CT scan image shows the typical slip of one vertebra over the other, confirming the diagnosis of spondylolisthesis. This condition often leads to chronic back pain and is frequently associated with nerve compression, particularly at the L5-S1 level.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Spinal metastasis: This condition involves the spread of cancerous cells to the spine, leading to bone destruction or pathological fractures. However, it does not present with a vertebral slip as seen in this case.

 

Option B. Paget’s disease: Paget’s disease is a disorder of bone remodeling, which leads to abnormally large, misshapen bones. While it can affect the spine, it does not typically present with vertebral slippage.

 

Option C. Renal osteodystrophy: This condition is associated with chronic kidney disease and affects bone density and structure. While it can lead to skeletal deformities, vertebral slippage (spondylolisthesis) is not characteristic of renal osteodystrophy.

 

Educational Objective:


Spondylolisthesis involves the slipping of one vertebra over another, typically visualized in imaging studies. The "beheaded dog" or "Scottish terrier sign" is a key radiographic feature of this condition.

questions.text: In context of biliary atresia, what is the typical duration of jaundice observed in infants? (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 2 weeks 

 

Biliary atresia typically presents with jaundice that is not evident at birth but becomes apparent within the first two weeks of life. Jaundice lasting longer than two weeks in a newborn can be indicative of biliary atresia, especially if it is conjugated hyperbilirubinemia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. 2 Months: While jaundice in biliary atresia often becomes noticeable after the first two weeks of life, it would likely persist and not resolve on its own, prompting further investigation well before two months of age if it is due to biliary atresia.

 

Option C. 2 years: Jaundice due to biliary atresia would be identified and treated well before a child reaches two years of age. If left untreated, biliary atresia can lead to liver failure within the first two years of life.

 

Option D. 48 hours: Physiological jaundice of the newborn typically appears within the first 24 to 72 hours after birth and resolves without treatment. Jaundice persisting beyond this period, especially if it's conjugated jaundice, requires further evaluation for pathological causes, including biliary atresia.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Persistent jaundice extending beyond two weeks of age in an infant can be indicative of biliary atresia and warrants prompt investigation and potential surgical intervention.

questions.text: A 60-year-old female underwent hip replacement. After 1 year, she developed fever and pain in the joint. Radiograph revealed loosening of prosthesis. The implant had to be removed. The histological image of the tissue adjoining the implant is shown below. What is the diagnosis?(AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Metallosis

 

  • The microscopic image shows multiple foci of extracellular metal deposits (seen as black deposits) surrounded by inflammatory cells, suggestive of metallosis.

 

METALLOSIS

 

  • Metallosis is a rare, potentially fatal complication after arthroplasty characterized by the deposition and build-up of metal debris in the soft tissues of the body, associated with metal-on-metal prosthetic devices, but it has also been described in non-metallic prostheses.
  • It is defined as aseptic fibrosis, local necrosis, or loosening of a device secondary to metal corrosion and release of wear debris.
  • It occurs due to metallic erosion and release of metallic debris products, which induce massive local cytokines liberation from inflammatory cells.
  • It can present with local/systemic symptoms and signs due to a chronic inflammatory host response.
  • The local effects have been described as pseudotumours or osteolysis.
  • The systemic effects are caused by an immunological response to metal debris, including constitutional symptoms such as nausea, vomiting and malaise, cognitive impairment, haematological abnormalities and neuromuscular changes.
  • Risk factor for the development of metallosis include female gender, bilateral implants, high doses of corticosteroids, renal insufficiency and a suppressed immune system.
  • Its histology is characterized by widespread lymphoplasmacytic and histiocytic infiltration around metal debris, foreign body giant cells, metal particles, extracellular metal deposits and intracytoplasmic debris in giant cells.
  • Treatment consists of surgical revision with replacement of the prosthesis components, complete surgical debridement of osteolytic lesions and bone grafting with allograft chips.
  • Complete removal of all metal debris is difficult and may result in extensive tissue damage.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Melanoma. Melanoma, also known as malignant melanoma, is a type of cancer that develops from the pigment-producing cells known as melanocytes. Melanomas typically occur in the skin. In women, they most commonly occur on the legs, while in men, they most commonly occur on the back. About 25% of melanomas develop from moles. Changes in a mole that can indicate melanoma include an increase in size, irregular edges, change in color, itchiness, or skin breakdown. The primary cause of melanoma is ultraviolet light (UV) exposure in those with low levels of the skin pigment melanin. Those with many moles, a history of affected family members, and poor immune function are at greater risk. Diagnosis is by biopsy. Using sunscreen and avoiding UV light may prevent melanoma. Treatment is typically removal of the melanoma and potentially affected tissue (border around the melanoma) by surgery. In those with slightly larger cancers, nearby lymph nodes may be tested for metastasis. For those in whom melanoma has spread, immunotherapy, biologic therapy, radiation therapy, or chemotherapy may improve survival. 

 

Option C. Ochronosis. Ochronosis is named for the reddish-brown hue of tissue termed "ochre-like". It is inborn error of metabolism. Ochronosis is due to deposition of a phenolic compound – "alkaptons" polymerizing into connective tissue, leading to black urine disease called alkaptonuria. Inherited in an autosomal recessive fashion, alkaptonuria is an inactive gene, mapped on chromosome 3q21-23 coding for the enzyme homogentisate 1,2 dioxygenase (HGD). The result is systemic sequestration of homogentisate, that upon the decay to benzoquinone, can irreversibly bind with collagen. Polymerization of this molecule takes on an iridescent dark hue, tinting affected tissue and turning urine black. Aside from just discoloration, these processes can cause degradation, degeneration, and developmental problems in all types of collagen. The earliest sign is from parents who notice infants’ diapers are black in color. This disease can be insidious and manifest later in life. Patients may present with back pain or large joint arthralgias in their post-teenage years or early 30s. Pigmentation of the sclera and pinna of the ear is often seen later in life. Constant tendon ruptures especially with minimal trauma. On physical examination, thickened Achilles tendon and bursa effusions are common. For alkaptonuria, a chromatography assay in the urine for homogentisate can be diagnostic, especially, if the color change is noted after being exposed to the air. A genetic test can determine the existence of the autosomal recessive disease.

 

Option D. Rosai-Dorfman syndrome. Rosai-Dorfman disease is a disease that occurs when the body produces too many histiocytes in the lymph nodes. These histiocytes accumulate in the cervical nodes most commonly. Histiocytes may also build up in the skin, upper respiratory tract, and sinuses. Rosai-Dorfman disease is seldom life-threatening. In many instances, the patient’s symptoms resolve on their own. The majority of patients experience enlarged lymph nodes on both sides of the neck. While often painless, these nodes can swell and grow rather larger. Swelling may also be reported in the lymph nodes of the groin, armpits, and in the central portion of the chest. This swelling may be accompanied by fever. The diagnosis is made following a tissue biopsy from the affected site. Though it is most commonly diagnosed in the first 10 years of life, it is also found in adults, affecting men and women equally. 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The image in the question shows extracellular metal deposits (black deposits) surrounded by inflammatory cells, suggestive of metallosis.
  • It is associated with metal-on-metal prosthetic devices.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents with long standing history of back pain for 20 years and chest tightness. Lateral radiograph of the cervical spine is shown. What is the diagnosis?(AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) DISH

 

DIFFUSE IDIOPATHIC SKELETAL HYPEROSTOSIS

 

  • Diffuse idiopathic skeletal hyperostosis (DISH) is a spon­dyloarthropathy also known as Forestier’s disease or ankylosing hyperostosis.
  • It is a noninflammatory disease, with the principal manifestation being calcification and ossification of spinal ligaments and the entheses.
  • Diffuse idiopathic skeletal hyperostosis is characterized by florid hyperostosis of the spine.
  • Marginal bony proliferation leads to the formation of anterior osseous ridges that fuse and give the appearance of flowing wax on the anterior bodies of the vertebrae on radiography.
  • Ossification of paraspinous ligaments, such as the anterior and posterior longitudinal ligaments, may be seen.
  • The whole spine may be involved, and bony ankylosis occurs, although the disc spaces and facet joints remain unaffected.
  • The thoracic spine is most commonly involved, although the cervical and lumbar regions may also be affected.
  • Lesions are most prominent anteriorly and along the right lateral aspect of the spine.
  • Intervertebral disc spaces are preserved, unless there is co-existing lumbar spondylosis, and sacroiliac and facet joints appear normal. This helps differentiate diffuse idiopathic skeletal hyperostosis from spondylosis and the spondyloarthritis.
  • Diffuse idiopathic skeletal hyperostosis is usually seen in the middle-aged and the elderly.
  • In advanced stages, the disease may look like melted candle wax. The calcification and ossification is most common in the right side of the spine.
  • The distinctive radiological feature of DISH is the continuous linear calcification along the anteromedial aspect of the thoracic spine.
  • The disease is not fatal, however some associated complications can lead to death. Complications include paralysis, dysphagia, and pulmonary infections.
  • DISH has no indication of a genetic link, and does not affect organs other than the lungs, which is only indirect due to the fusion of the rib cage.
  • DISH may be discovered as a radiological abnormality, as mentioned above, without any symptoms.
  • Morning stiffness is also noticed in almost two-thirds of patients.
  • Calcification and ossification may be seen at peripheral entheseal sites, including the shoulder, iliac crest, ischial tuberosity, trochanters of the hip, tibial tuberosities, patellae, and bones of the hands and/or feet.
  • Treatment: NSAIDs can be helpful in relieving pain and inflammation associated with DISH.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ankylosing spondylitis. Also known as Marie-Strumpell or Bechterew’s disease. It is a seronegative chronic inflammatory disease affecting the spine and sacroiliac joints. HLA B27 is positive in 90% patients. Sacroiliitis is the earliest manifestation with features of both enthesitis & synovitis. It is most commonly seen in young males aged 15-25 years. Most common symptom is dull backache, insidious in onset, associated with morning stiffness for few hours that improves with activity. Question mark (?) posture due to hyperkyphosis of thoracic spine and loss of lumbar lordosis. Cervical spine involvement is usually late and show forward stooping and loss of extension and rotation. Anterior uveitis is the most common extra-articular manifestation. Spine radiograph shows loss of lumbar lordosis, haziness of SI joint margins (earliest change), calcification of supraspinous & interspinous ligaments (Dagger sign), Trolley/Tram-track sign i.e., three linear radiopaque lines due to ligament calcification, Bamboo spine appearance due to syndesmophytes.

 

 

Sacroiliitis

 

 

A. Trolley/Tram track sign; B. Bamboo Spine

 

 

Dagger Sign

 

Option C. Klippel feil syndrome. It is congenital fusion of one or more cervical vertebrae presenting with classical triad of limited neck motion, low hair line and short ‘web' neck (prominent trapezius muscle). Clinical features includes abnormal head position, true torticollis, restricted range of motion, without an obvious SCM contracture, congenital osseous fusions (synostosis) and failure of segmentation of the cervical spine.

 

 

Option D. Sprengel deformity. It consists of permanent elevation of the shoulder girdle due to developmental defect. The scapula is smaller in its vertical diameter and appears broad. It lies high in position. Para scapular muscles are composed of imperfectly developed muscle fibers or fibrous tissue. From the superior angle of scapula, a sheet or band like structure composed of fibrous tissue cartilage or bone extends upwards to attach to the transverse process of several cervical vertebrae, known as Omovertebral bar.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The given x-ray image shows DISH i.e., diffuse idiopathic skeletal hyperostosis, which is the non-inflammatory disease, with calcification and ossification of spinal ligaments and the enthuses, mainly at the thoracic spine.

questions.text: What is the likely diagnosis based on the MRCP image? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans.  A) Choledochal cyst

 

The MRCP (Magnetic Resonance Cholangiopancreatography) image shows a fusiform dilatation of the common bile duct (CBD), which is characteristic of a choledochal cyst, specifically Type 1. Type 1 choledochal cysts are the most common type and are characterized by this distinctive fusiform dilatation of the CBD. Choledochal cysts are congenital anomalies of the bile duct that can present with symptoms such as abdominal pain, jaundice, or pancreatitis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Cholangiocarcinoma: This is a malignant tumor of the bile ducts that typically appears as a mass, often associated with bile duct obstruction. The classic presentation on imaging is a mass lesion, often seen at the perihilar (Klatskin tumor) or distal bile ducts, which is not observed in the provided image.

 

Option C. Caroli disease: This rare congenital disorder involves the dilation of intrahepatic bile ducts, not extrahepatic ones like the CBD. A key imaging feature of Caroli disease is the "central dot sign," where dilated bile ducts contain a small dot representing a portal vein radical, which is absent in this image.

 

Option D. Choledocholithiasis: This condition involves the presence of stones within the bile ducts, which appear as signal voids on MRCP. The provided image does not show such signal voids, ruling out this diagnosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A fusiform dilatation of the common bile duct on MRCP is characteristic of a Type 1 choledochal cyst, the most common type of choledochal cyst.

questions.text: Identify the structure marked by the arrow?(NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Superior mesenteric vein

 

The structure shown by the arrow is SMV.

 

SMV is on the right, while SMA is on the left (Remember "SMAL").

 

They can be identified by the uncinate process at this level

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Superior Mesenteric Vein can be distinguished on a CT scan by its position to the right of the Superior Mesenteric Artery, and its relation to the uncinate process. Remembering "SMAL" (Superior Mesenteric Artery Left, Superior Mesenteric Vein Right) can aid in identification during diagnostic imaging.

questions.text: What is the likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans.  B) Chiari malformation

 

Chiari malformation is diagnosed by the presence of tonsillar herniation below the foramen magnum. In the given image, the cerebellar tonsils are seen herniating more than 5 mm below the line drawn between the basion (the lower part of the clivus) and the opisthion (the lower part of the occiput), which is characteristic of Chiari I malformation. This displacement of the tonsils is known as tonsillar ectopia, a hallmark feature of Chiari malformation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Dandy Walker malformation: This condition is characterized by an enlarged posterior fossa, a posterior fossa cyst, and agenesis of the cerebellar vermis, none of which are seen in the provided image. Therefore, Dandy Walker malformation is not the correct diagnosis.

 

Option C. Vein of Galen malformation: This malformation presents as a large midline vascular structure, typically a signal void due to the dilated vein, which is absent in the provided image. The lack of these vascular changes rules out Vein of Galen malformation.

 

Option D. Encephalocele: Encephaloceles are characterized by herniation of brain tissue through a defect in the skull. There is no evidence of brain tissue protruding from the skull in the image, ruling out encephalocele.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Chiari malformation is diagnosed by the inferior displacement of the cerebellar tonsils below the foramen magnum, typically more than 5 mm, seen on imaging.

questions.text: What is the likely diagnosis based on the given image? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Chronic osteomyelitis

 

The provided CT scan image shows significant periosteal thickening and sclerosis within the diaphysis of the bone, accompanied by central lucency. These radiological features are characteristic of chronic osteomyelitis. Chronic osteomyelitis is a long-standing infection of the bone, leading to extensive periosteal reaction, sclerosis, and central areas of bone destruction.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Ewing sarcoma: Typically presents with a large soft tissue mass and periosteal reaction. The symmetrical soft tissue in the image makes this diagnosis less likely.

 

Option C. Osteosarcoma: Usually arises in the metaphysis, with characteristic sunburst periosteal reaction and periosteal lifting, not observed in this diaphyseal lesion.

 

Option D. Fracture: Would present with a distinct fracture line, which is not visible in the image provided. The periosteal reaction and sclerosis are also not typical for a simple fracture.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Chronic osteomyelitis is characterized by periosteal thickening, sclerosis, and central lucency within the bone, which are key diagnostic features visible on imaging.

questions.text: Diagnose the X-ray as shown below: (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Osteosarcoma


Osteosarcoma is a type of malignant bone tumor that typically shows characteristic radiographic features such as the "sunburst" or "sun ray" appearance, which is caused by the tumor's aggressive growth pattern. In addition to this, Codman’s triangle may be visible, which occurs when the tumor lifts the periosteum off the bone, forming a triangular area of new bone formation. The lower end of the femur is a common site for osteosarcoma, as well as other long bones in the body.

 

In the provided X-rays, the sun ray appearance is clearly visible, making osteosarcoma the correct diagnosis in this case.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Chondroblastoma: This tumor typically presents with calcifications in the epiphyseal (end) regions of bones, particularly in the upper end of the humerus. However, chondroblastoma does not present with a sun ray appearance.

 

 

Option B. Chondrosarcoma: This is another malignant tumor, but it primarily affects the upper end of the femur or pelvis. The X-ray for chondrosarcoma typically shows dense calcifications, but not the sun ray pattern associated with osteosarcoma.

 

 

Option C. Ewing's sarcoma: This tumor often presents with a diaphyseal (shaft) lesion in long bones and can cause an "onion-skin" appearance due to the layered periosteal reaction. It does not exhibit the sun ray pattern seen in osteosarcoma.

 

 

Educational Objective:
 

The sun ray appearance and Codman’s triangle in X-rays are key indicators of osteosarcoma, especially in the lower end of long bones like the femur.

questions.text: A child presented with the following deformity and history of recurrent tooth abscess. On lab investigation, his serum calcium was normal, serum phosphorus was normal/reduced, serum PTH was normal, and ALP was increased. What is the diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans.  A)  Hypophosphatemic rickets

 

The key finding in this case is the normal PTH level. In metabolic bone disorders like rickets, parathyroid hormone (PTH) is often elevated, but in hypophosphatemic rickets, PTH remains normal. The patient also has normal/reduced serum phosphorus, which is another critical feature of hypophosphatemic rickets. Although serum alkaline phosphatase (ALP) is increased, this can also be seen in other forms of rickets, but the normal PTH differentiates this condition from others like nutritional rickets and Vitamin D-dependent rickets (VDDR). Additionally, recurrent tooth abscesses and bone deformities, as shown in the image, are typical clinical features of hypophosphatemic rickets.

 

Additional Information

 

Different type of Rickets:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Nutritional rickets: In nutritional rickets, calcium may be normal to low, phosphorus is usually low, and PTH is typically elevated. This is inconsistent with the findings in the current case where PTH is normal.

 

Option C. VDDR 1 (Vitamin D-dependent rickets type 1): This condition involves a defect in the 1-alpha hydroxylation of Vitamin D, leading to low levels of active Vitamin D. Here, phosphorus is low, and PTH is elevated, which does not match the patient's normal PTH level.

 

Option D. VDDR 2 (Vitamin D-dependent rickets type 2): In this condition, there is end-organ resistance to active Vitamin D (1,25-dihydroxyvitamin D), leading to high levels of 1,25-dihydroxyvitamin D. Phosphorus is low, and PTH is elevated, again differing from the normal PTH level observed in this patient.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hypophosphatemic rickets is characterized by normal PTH levels, normal/reduced phosphorus levels, and increased alkaline phosphatase (ALP). If PTH is normal in a case of suspected rickets, hypophosphatemic rickets should be strongly considered.

questions.text: Identify: (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans.  B) Venous ulcer

 

The correct answer is Venous ulcer. Venous ulcers, also known as ulcers of varicose veins, typically occur on the medial aspect of the lower leg, just above the medial malleolus. They are often found in the "gaiter" area and are associated with chronic venous insufficiency. The ulcers are usually shallow with irregular borders, and the surrounding skin may show signs of venous stasis, such as hyperpigmentation and edema. The presence of varicose veins and the ulcer's location on the medial side strongly indicate a venous origin.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ischemic ulcer: Ischemic ulcers are generally located on the tips of toes, pressure points, or other areas that experience reduced blood flow. They have well-defined borders and a punched-out appearance. The location and presentation in this case do not match ischemic ulcers.

 

Option C. Trophic ulcer: Trophic ulcers are usually associated with neuropathy, often seen in diabetic patients. They occur on pressure points such as the plantar surface of the foot and are characterized by a loss of protective sensation. The location above the medial malleolus does not fit with trophic ulcers.

 

Option D.  Infectious ulcer: Infectious ulcers can occur anywhere on the body and are characterized by overt signs of infection like pus, redness, and warmth. While infection can complicate venous ulcers, the primary cause in this case is venous insufficiency, not infection.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Venous ulcers are typically found on the medial aspect of the lower leg, above the medial malleolus, and are associated with chronic venous insufficiency. Recognizing their characteristic location and appearance is crucial for diagnosis.

questions.text: What is the likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Chronic SDH

 

Chronic Subdural Hematoma (SDH) is characterized by a hypodense (dark) appearance on CT scans due to the older age of the blood collection, which becomes less dense over time. The hallmark shape of a subdural hematoma is crescent-shaped or moon-like, indicating that the bleed is located between the dura mater and the arachnoid membrane, spreading widely along the brain’s surface.

 

In this image:

 

  • The hypodense (dark) appearance confirms that the bleed is chronic.
  • The crescent shape seen in the scan is typical for a subdural hematoma (SDH).

 

These findings are classic for a chronic SDH.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Acute EDH (Epidural Hematoma): Acute EDH appears as a biconvex (lens-shaped) collection that is hyperdense (bright) on imaging due to fresh bleeding. It is not crescent-shaped and does not appear hypodense as seen in this image.

 

Option B. Chronic EDH: Chronic EDH is rare and still appears biconvex, like acute EDH. The imaging features shown here do not match EDH patterns.

 

Option D. Acute SDH: Acute SDH appears hyperdense (bright) because the blood is fresh and denser. It is crescent-shaped but does not match the hypodense characteristics of a chronic bleed.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A crescent or moon-shaped, hypodense (dark) collection on a CT scan suggests a chronic subdural hematoma (SDH).

Ans. D. 65 years

 

OSTEOPOROSIS (V > H > C)

 

  • Bone mineral density is measured by DEXA scan (65 years onwards).
  • Normal Ca2+, PO‑4, ALP
  • Hemiplegic – Humerus maximum loss of bone mineral density

Codfish Vertebrae

  • Bone mineral density screening by DEXA scan is recommended at the age more than 65 years.

questions.text: During excision of ranula along with sublingual gland, which structure is most likely to be injured? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Lingual nerve

 

A ranula is a type of mucocele found on the floor of the mouth, associated with the sublingual gland. During the surgical excision of a ranula along with the sublingual gland, the lingual nerve is at risk of being injured. The lingual nerve runs close to the sublingual gland and is responsible for sensation in the anterior two-thirds of the tongue. Due to its proximity, it is the structure most likely to be damaged during such surgical procedures.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Mylohyoid muscle: The mylohyoid muscle forms the floor of the mouth and is situated below the sublingual gland. It is less likely to be injured during the excision of a ranula as the procedure primarily involves the tissues above this muscle.

 

Option C. Submental artery: The submental artery supplies blood to the floor of the mouth and the mylohyoid muscle. While it is in the general area, it is not as closely associated with the sublingual gland as the lingual nerve is, making it less likely to be injured during this specific procedure.

 

Option D. Sublingual artery: The sublingual artery supplies blood to the sublingual gland and the surrounding tissues. Although it is close to the surgical site, the risk of injury to the lingual nerve is higher due to its course and proximity to the gland.

 

Educational Objective:

 

During the excision of a ranula and the sublingual gland, the lingual nerve is the structure most likely to be injured due to its anatomical position relative to the sublingual gland. This nerve is responsible for sensory innervation of the anterior two-thirds of the tongue, and its injury can result in significant sensory deficits.

choices.text: To hold bone fragments with traction
For creating a gap in wound

questions.text: What is the use of the given instrument?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) To hold bone fragments with traction.

 

Explanation:

 

BONE HOLDING FORCEPS

 

  • Bone holding forceps are used to manipulate bone fragments in place during surgery.
  • They are typically used in orthopedic procedures, such as the repair of fractures or the realignment of bones.
  • These forceps are designed to grip the bone securely without damaging it, and can be adjusted to apply the appropriate amount of force to hold the bone in the desired position.

 

 

  • They allow for more precise manipulation of the bones during surgery and can help ensure the success of the procedure.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. To hold bone and plate. For this purpose, a Bone-Plate Holding Forcep is used. They are designed to aid in the reduction of fractures and can help secure a plate in place during installation. Aid in the reduction of fractures such as spiral, transverse, compound, oblique, or butterfly. The clamp can also be used to secure a plate in place while the screw holes are being drilled and screws inserted. The fracture site can also be manipulated with the clamp being used as a lever. It has teeth in the jaws for a better grip and a ratchet locking handle for use on various bone diameters.

 

 

Option C. To cut the bone. For this purpose, a Bone Cutter is used.

 

 

Option D. For creating a gap in wound. Wound Spreader is a specialized device that is used to grasp, retract and manipulate the edges of wounds and incisions, in order to spread the space between them and localize surgical targets with ease.

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • To hold the bone with traction during the surgical procedure, a Bone Holding Forcep is used.
